Measure: Policy instruments targeting NOX and SOX emissions

Measure: Fuel quality requirements such as through limiting the maximum sulphur content of the fuel oils as loaded, bunkered, and subsequently used onboard.
Source(s):
SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking;
IMO, 2019: Sulphur oxides (SOx) and Particulate Matter (PM) – Regulation 14, http://www.imo.org/en/OurWork/Environment/PollutionPrevention/AirPollution/Pages/Sulphur-oxides-(SOx)-%E2%80%93-Regulation-14.aspx

Measure: Designation of sulphur Emission Control Areas (ECAs), are established to limit the emission of SOx and particulate matter.
Source(s):
SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking;
IMO, 2019: Sulphur oxides (SOx) and Particulate Matter (PM) – Regulation 14, http://www.imo.org/en/OurWork/Environment/PollutionPrevention/AirPollution/Pages/Sulphur-oxides-(SOx)-%E2%80%93-Regulation-14.aspx

Measure: Implementation of Energy Efficiency Management Plans
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Hydrogen use as fuel
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Use of Biofuels
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Ship speed reduction – reduction of fuel use and noise
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Cooperation for less ships' emissions for the promotion of cooperation and sharing of knowledge on emission reduction methods between stakeholders of the shipping sector. E.g. the Platform Ships’ Emissions in The Netherlands aims to unite business and environmental interests.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: The Clean Shipping Index is an initiative lead by leading international cargo owners that aim to evaluate the environmental performance of ships and shipowners. The CSI allows for a comparison of environmental performance based on air emission (i.e. CO2, NOX, SOX and PM). Also, the index includes performance of ships regarding their handling of waste on board and water discharges, such as sewage and ballast water, but also chemical discharge. Moreover, the performance of the shipowner on general CO2 emissions policy (e.g. companywide CO2 emission target) and recycling policy on board of its ships feeds into the CSI. By now, 30  large cargo owners form the clean shipping network have joined the programme. The CSI is calculated based on entered data by the shipowners into the database. Results can be delivered for each vessel and per cargo carrier and allows for a comparison between the shipping fleets (CSI, 2015a, 2015b).
Source(s): SHEBA 2015: Deliverable 1.1, type RE, Drivers for the shipping sector

Measure: Design of more fuel-efficient ships (Triple-E ships)
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) is a natural gas that is cooled down to -163°C and temporarily transformed into liquid form, which takes up 600 times less space than it does as gas. It comprises mostly methane gas. It produces lower emissions of carbon dioxide during combustion and nitric oxide compared with using oil. It has considerably lower emissions of sulphur compounds and particles.
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es;
SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Energy Efficiency Design Index is used to calculate a vessel’s energy efficiency. The calculation is based on a complex formula, which includes: the ship’s emissions, capacity, and speed. The lower a ship’s EEDI, the more energy- efficient it is and the lower its negative impact on the environment. The required EEDI represents a minimum energy efficiency requirement for new ships depending on ship type and size beginning with a baseline value in 2013 and  raising successively in three steps until 2025
Source(s):
SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking;
MAN Diesel & Turbo, Undated, EEDI – Energy efficiency design index.

Measure: The Environmental Ship Index (ESI) was initiated by the World Ports Climate Initiative and aims to improve the environmental performance of sea going vessels. It evaluates the environmental performance of ships in regards to air pollutants in a score (in particular for NOX and SOX emissions) and aims to reward ships for improving their environmental performance. A ship’s index value can be improved if the ship is prepared for on shore power supply and if two of the Energy Efficiency Operational Indicator data sets are reported. The ESI supports ports and other interested parties to encourage ships to improve their environmental performance. The ESI Score ranges from 0 to 100, where 0 is set for a ship that meets the environmental regulations in force and 100 for a ship that emits no SOX and no NOX and also reports or monitors its energy efficiency. Currently, the best performing ships reach around 60 points. LNG carriers reach up to 80 points (ESI, 2015). The ESI bureau of International Association of Ports and Harbours is the administration for the ESI. E.g. port of le Havre, France, Bremerhaven, Germany, Rotterdam, The Netherlands.
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es; 
SHEBA 2015: Deliverable 1.1, type RE, Drivers for the shipping sector

Measure: Fuel saving: slow steaming, weather routing, contra-rotating propellers, propulsion efficiency devices
Source(s): https://ec.europa.eu/clima/policies/transport/shipping_en

Measure: Retrofitting ships – noise
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Electric driven ships & improvements on energy efficiency in the short term – reduce GHG emissions
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Promoting renewables (especially battery driven ships) – GHG emissions reduction and noise
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: To reduce chemical substance pollution focus on antifouling paint; promoting alternatives and funding respective research activities could decrease the biocidal release rate
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Cleaning technologies to reduce air emissions (scrubber)
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Type of fuels to reduce air emissions (LNG or renewables are beneficial)
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Fuel efficiency standards to reduce air emissions
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Carbon tax or emission trading scheme
Source(s): SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking

Measure: Onshore Power Supply for seagoing vessels to improve air quality in ports and port cities. Onboard-generated power from diesel auxiliary engines are replaced by electricity generated onshore. This leads to an important reduction of air pollutants and carbon dioxide emissions, in addition to noise. E.g. port of Gothenburg, Trelleborg and Ystad, Sweden.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Using contaminated dredged materials to create new land using principles of Circular Economy, example case study: port of Gävle in Sweden.
Source(s): Angela Carpenter, Rodrigo Lozano, Kaisu Sammalisto, Linda Astner, Securing a port's future through Circular Economy: Experiences from the Port of Gävle in contributing to sustainability, Marine Pollution Bulletin, Volume 128, 2018, Pages 539-547,https://doi.org/10.1016/j.marpolbul.2018.01.065

Measure: Sulphur-free fuel for port authority vessels and floating equipment to reduce impacts on air quality and conserve energy. E.g. implementation in port of Hamburg.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Improving air quality and bulk material handling performance. E.g. port of Rauma, Finland, build a new unloading funnel and changing and encasing the conveyor belt system leading to the storage. Investment costs were 4 million euros.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Management of traffic within the port area to improve air quality and reduce noise levels. For example by improving the traffic flow of vehicles into and out of the terminal to reduce congestion and associated air quality issues, or force trucks to follow a specific route (i.e. avoiding residential areas around the port). E.g. port of Dover, UK, Ghent, Belgium.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Shore-side electricity services for barges to reduce impacts on air quality. This includes the renewal/installations of shore-side power infrastructure for barges within the port are. E.g. port of Antwerp, Belgium.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Providing a LNG terminal to facilitate the use of LNG as ship fuel. E.g. port of Gothenburg, Sweden, Bremerhaven, Germany.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Energy management including the use of renewable energies (e.g. photovoltaic structures, solar power installations, wind energy). Possibly the development of a Port Energy Environmental Plan (PEEP) with the scope of stimulating and developing the activities linked to the production of energy from renewable sources and of limiting energy use in its own territory. Example port of Genoa was the first port in Italy that applied this approach with the aim to reduce its CO2 emissions by 20,000t a year (investment of 60 million euros). Other example for using renewable energy sources is the port of Hamburg, Germany. E.g. Bremerhaven, Germany, Valencia, Spain.
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es;
Michele Acciaro, Hilda Ghiara, Maria Inés Cusano, Energy management in seaports: A new role for port authorities, Energy Policy,Volume 71, 2014,Pages 4-12, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.enpol.2014.04.013

Measure: Keeping quayside clear from ice for berthing. The removal of ice between quay and hull of ships can take a while during winter months. Unloading/loading has to wait until all ice is If removed, which delays shipping schedules. Keeping quays clear of ice all the time can reduce the ships waiting time and hence its energy consumption and emissions. Port of HaminaKotka Ltd, Finland.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Rail shuttles operating to and from ports to freight terminals inland. They can allow large volumes of goods to reach the port's customers quickly and efficiently. E.g. Gothenburg, Sweden, where RAILPORT Scandinavia reaches freight terminals in Sweden and Norway.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Reduce lightning area for port operating yards, as lightning yards represents one of the largest energy consuming installations in ports. E.g. Port of HaminaKotka Ltd, Finland
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Using the Barge Traffic System (BTS), which is an operational planning instrument for container barge and terminal operators. It allows for a more time-efficient cargo handling on the terminal side and less delays for barges waiting at berth. E.g. port of Antwerp, Belgium.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Implementing measures to reduce noise impacts, such as for example by applying noise barriers to prevent noise propagation from industrial Operations and port/railway traffic. E.g. port of Bremerhaven, Germany, Tallinn, Estonia, Trelleborg and Stockholm, Sweden.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Green charges for port railway, where activities include environmental components in railway charges and an eco-tariff for low-noise wagons used by companies operating on the port railway network.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Optimisation of waste management. For example by implementing separate Waste Management Plans for ship waste and port-generated waste, increase of recycling and production of energy from waste. E.g. port of Dover, UK, Tallinn, Estonia, Valencia, Spain.
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es;
ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Encouraging marine litter collection that is collected by fishermen at sea as by-catch. E.g. Groningen Seaports, The Netherlands.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Waste management for cruise liners as cruise ships carry large amounts of solid and liquid waste. Available facilities include improved reception facilities and recycling programmes. E.g. Ports of Stockholm, Sweden.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Mobile Technological Handling Station (MTK) for liquid oil-containing waste. This is based on new innovative technological set and energy saving solutions for optimum handling of oil-containing waste (incl. bilge, slops, sludge etc). E.g. Tallin, Estonia.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Reception of black and grey water by providing facilities for offloading black and grey water. E.g. Stockholm, Sweden, Kalundborg, Denmark.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Control and reduction of water used for irrigation within the port area, as for example for water used for irrigation of green spaces or cleaning of public spaces. Consumption of water is monitored. To reduce water use, native plant species can be planted and education programs for gardening teams are organised. E.g. Port of Setúbal and Sesimbra (APSS), Portugal.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Sustainable processing of wastewater by constructing a Saline Wastewater Treatment Plant (SWWTP), which collects and treats salt water from several industrial operators. E.g. Groningen Seaports, The Netherlands.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Filter equipment in surface water drains that aim to reduce inputs of harmful substances into the environment.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Water quality management as for example by having a port-wide Oil Spill Contingency plan in place and oil spill trained staff, or recycling and reusing of water and preventing debris from draining back into the harbour. E.g. Port of Dover, UK, Port of Nantes Saint-Nazaire, France.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Existence of an Environmental Policy
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es;
ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Environmental Policy makes reference to ESPO’s guideline documents
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Existence of an inventory of relevant environmental legislation
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Existence of an inventory of Significant Environmental Aspects (SEA)
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Definition of objectives and targets for environmental improvement
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Carbon capture
Source(s): SHEBA 2015: Deliverable 1.1, type RE, Drivers for the shipping sector

Measure: Air quality management system, as for example in Muuga Harbour (Tallinn, Estonia), with two automatic monitoring stations coupled with modelling system. The monitoring stations measure VOC, aromatic hydrocarbons (BTEX), hydrogen sulphide (H2S), Sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOX) and fine particulate matter (PM10) concentrations and meteorological conditions. Possible pollution sources are identified in case of high levels of measures pollution. The data is used to improve measures for future situations.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Environmental Control Panel (e.g. port of A Coruña, Spain) which is a tool which includes a system of indicators to provide public information on the collection of environmental, meteorological and oceanographic data of the port.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Air quality monitoring that covers concentrations of nitrogen oxides (NOX), particles (particulate matter), sulphur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and ozone (O3). E.g.Turku and Helsinki harbour.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Cooperation between ports for environmental aspects, as for example to widen the use of shore power, receiving black- and greywater and enabling bunkering of LNG. E.g. ports of Helsinki, Finland, and Turku, Estonia in line with the EU Strategy for the Baltic Sea region.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Economic support for cleaner shipping means that vessels that opt for cleaner fuel whilst operating in the port's fairways will be compensated financially. This includes vessels classified as “green” according to an international index or financial support for vessels to support their conversion to run on LNG (liquefied natural gas) or equivalent clean fuels. E.g. port of Gothenburg, Sweden.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Stimulating investments on state-of-the-art terminal equipment a sustainable policy initiative to stimulate investments in state-of-the-art terminal equipment, which is green, such as: forklifts, straddle carriers, mobile cranes, reach stackers and ro-ro-trackers. E.g. port of Antwerp, Belgium
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Port pricing/environmental charging scheme, e.g. rebates on port dues that range from 0,5% to 20% to vessels that are certified under the certain schemes/index (i.e. environmental Ship Index, Green Award, the Clean Shipping Index, and Blue Angel), or discounts on waste collection tax. Existence of a Certified Environmental
Source(s):
SHEBA 2018, Policy Brief - Policies for sustainable shipping in the Baltic Sea – a ranking;
COGEA, 2017. Study on differentiated port infrastructure charges to promote environmentally friendly maritime transport activities and sustainable transportation, Final report

Measure: Calculation of the port authority carbon footprint, reporting and setting reduction targets to assess and improve environmental performance. E.g. Valencia, Spain.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Constructions/adaptations for sustainable buildings in which port authorities are located, for example through the building of passive houses, houses with lower energy consumption, or renewable energy use etc. E.g. Setúbal and Sesimbra (APSS), Portugal, Gent, Belgium, Aalborg, Denmark.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Energy efficiency audits on a voluntary basis for port operators. The audits are conducted for a modest sum and provide the port operators with concrete proposals on how to improve their energy efficiency in an economically feasible way. E.g. port of Antwerp, Belgium.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Adoption of the World Ports Climate Declaration from 2008, which requires ports to: Reduce greenhouse gas emissions from ocean-going shipping, reduce greenhouse gas emissions from port operations and development, reduce greenhouse gas emissions from hinterland transport, enhance the use of renewable energy and develop and provide CO2 inventories. E.g. Gothenburg, Sweden.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Monitoring noise levels from port activities. E.g. port of Bremerhaven, Germany.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Environmental complaints desk where residents can complain regarding issues arising from the port, such as smell, dust and noise nuisance. This allows for the port authorities to have a focal point for complaints and be aware of the local perception of nuisance. Communication with residence is improved. E.g. port of Ghent, Belgium.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Incentive-based fee system for waste delivery by ships. The fee system includes a strong incentive towards maximum delivery of ship-generated waste, without limits in terms of volumes.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Engaging with stakeholders regarding waste reception facilities, where stakeholders include ships’ agents and waste collectors to facilitate waste collection within the port. E.g. Port of Rotterdam, The Netherlands.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Collection of floating waste from the sheltered waters of the port, i.e. collecting all floating waste from the water surface. E.g. Port of Valencia, Spain.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Environmental monitoring programme that monitors different aspects, such as air quality, surface water and sediment, dredging activities and noise levels. E.g. port of Valencia, Spain.
Source(s):
ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es;
ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Reporting environmental information and consulting with stakeholders, as for example through a port website where information on environmental matters is shared and published. Information should be easily accessible, and updated on a regular basis. Also, annual newsletters can contribute to information activities. Regular stakeholder meetings (e.g. quarterly forums) ensure a constant exchange on environmental issues. E.g. Port of Dover, United Kingdom.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Installation of a Network for sustainable development of the port with neighbouring businesses, which focus on different aspects, including environment and energy. The aim is collaboration, sharing of knowledge and industrial symbiosis. E.g. Port of Aalborg, Denmark.
Source(s): ESPO 2012, Green Guide, Annex 1 – Good practice examples in line with the 5 Es

Measure: Management System –EMS (ISO, EMAS, PERS)
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Environmental training programme for port employees
Source(s):
ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018
Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Environmental responsibilities of key personnel are documented
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Publicly available environmental report
Source(s): ESPO 2018, ESPO ENVIRONMENTAL REPORT 2018, EcoPortsinSights 2018

Measure: Port expansion, contraction or relocation
Source(s): Covil, C. (2012).  “SuPort : Appraising Port Sustainability”. http://www.unols.org/sites/default/files/GW_ap17_SuPort_Arup.pdf

Measure: Cold-ironing (on shore power supply) (e.g., Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s):
Covil, C. (2012).  “SuPort : Appraising Port Sustainability”. http://www.unols.org/sites/default/files/GW_ap17_SuPort_Arup.pdf 
Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Emission control area
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Lower tax and duties if carriers use the ultra low sulphur diesel oil (e.g. as done in Singapore)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: International Association of ports and Harbours (IAPH) had its port environment committee launch the World ports Climate Initiative programme, and 59 of its members have given their commitment to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Encourage quayside container terminal operators to install solar and wind power lighting systems (e.g. as done in Kaohsiung port)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Speed reduction after landfall (e.g., Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Using electrically powered equipment (e.g., Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Willingness to reuse recyclable resources (e.g. Kaohsiung, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Marine biology preservation & protection (e.g. Shanghai & Shenzhen ports)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Spill prevention during disconnection of cargo pipeline
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Regulation on noise & vibration from discharging equipment (e.g., Shenzhen port)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Ballast water pollutant prevention (e.g., Kaohsiung, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Singapore ports)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Sewage processing and water resource control (e.g., Kaohsiung, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Singapore ports)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Air pollution avoidance (toxic gas regulation) (e.g., Kaohsiung, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Singapore ports)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Encourage fuel switching to use of low-sulphur fuel (e.g., Hong Kong, and Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s):
Covil, C. (2012).  “SuPort : Appraising Port Sustainability”. http://www.unols.org/sites/default/files/GW_ap17_SuPort_Arup.pdf 
Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Using substitute energy and energy saving device (e.g., Kaohsiung, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Avoid dust pollutant during loading and discharging (e.g. Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach)
Source(s): Lirn, T. C., Wu, Y.-C., & Chen, Y. (2013). Green performance criteria for sustainable ports in Asia. International Journal of Physical Distribution & Logistics Management, 43(5/6), pp.427–451.

Measure: Sediment and Erosion Control to prevent or reduce impact during construction activites (e.g. building construction, utility construction, pavement removal and installation, bulkhead renovations and isntallation. Measures include tho minimize the amount of time an area is without cover, minimize the quantity of soil exposed at one time, prevent runoff from off-site areas from flowing across disturbed areas, plant grasses, shrubs, or ground cover plants in drainage pathways to slow erosion, create buffer zones between construction area and storm drain/receiving water.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empd-1.pdf

Measure: Buildings Renovation and Demolition to prevent or reduce the release of contaminants associated with building renovation or demolition projects. Demolition debris must be stored and disposed of properly, all abatement should be performed in accordance with local, state,and federal requirements, recycling of construction debris.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empd-2.pdf

Measure: Bulkhead, Pier, and Dock Construction to prevent or reduce impactsfrom construction of piers, docks, and bulkheads. Select the most appropriate “windows” of time to conduct construction  activities (i.e. Study marine life in the construction area to help determine mitigation requirements, if necessary). Use piers and bulkheads made of substances which are long lasting and will not release toxic substances into the environment. Provide adequate space to allow for safe management of: Solid waste, Fuels, Sanitary  wastes, Fish  wastes.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empd-3.pdf

Measure: Automobile Storage and Transport, Prevent discharge of pollutants related to storage of vehicles,including car washing activities,and accidental spills and leaks from fueling or maintenance activities. E.g. when practicable, design new facilities to minimize travel distance from off-loading and on-loading facilities to storage area to minimize air emissions, slope storage areas to enhance collection through separate storm drain system, separate vehicle washing areas should be designated and installed.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-1.pdf

Measure: Building and Grounds Maintenance, prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants to surface and groundwater and the air from building and grounds maintenance. Incorporate landscaped areas into project design. Land-scaped areas are pervious and will result in less run off discharged from a site. Incorporate design considerations such as leaving or planting native vegetation to reduce irrigation, fertilizer, andpesticide needs.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-2.pdf

Measure: Prevent emissions of dusts andentrainment of sediments in runoff from dry bulk storage and handling activities. E.g. cover storage and handling facilities where practicable and necessary, Runoff from cleaning area to sanitary sewer or industrial treatment facility, install filtering mechanisms in storm drain system to minimize transport of solids to storm water.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-3.pdf

Measure: Prevent releases from bulk liquid storage and handling facilities. E.g. Ensure adequate secondary containment for catastrophic failures, provide separating mechanisms, such as oil/water separators, to keep spills and leaks from stormwater, maintain oil/water separators, provide liners under storage facilities to ensure that no releasesto groundwater occur, provide overfill protection and alarms.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities.  https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-4.pdf

Measure: Prevent release of pollutants from the handling and storage of chemicals in 55-gallon drums or smaller quantities. E.g. cover chemical storage areas, raise storage area above surrounding ground surface tominimize run-on of stormwater.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-5.pdf

Measure: Prevent fuel spills and leaksfrom fueling operations. E.g. Design fueling areas to prevent the run-on of storm water and the run off of spills, cover the fueling area, use a perimeter drain, or slope the fueling area to a dead end sumpor  oil/water  separator.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-6.pdf

Measure: Prevent discharge of pollutants from painting or paint stripping operations performed on vessels, vehicles, equipment, or containers. E.g. designate special areas for painting and paint stripping, design areas to minimize releases, pave surfaces, preferably with concrete to allow easier removal of spills or stripping material, slope surface to allow capture of spills.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-7.pdf

Measure: Prevent discharge of contaminants associated with solidwaste handling. E.g. Design new facilities to prevent exposure to stormwater, cover storage facilities to prevent rainwater from carrying contaminants to storm drains, berm area to prevent run on of stormwater and to minimize runoff of contaminants.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-8.pdf

Measure: Protect marine mammals andother sensitive marine life from ship strikes, ship docking procedures, and other port activities. E.g. work closely with federal, state, and local regulatory agencies, as well as local advocacy groups todesign an effective mitigation program. Develop procedures for sighting and avoiding species. Identify habitat and habits on nautical charts for easy distribution to shippers and the public.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-9.pdf

Measure: Promote increased public access and recreational opportunities while preventing releases of pollutants associated with the use of these areas. E.g. accommodate current use and future growth; conduct plan-ning studies, if necessary, provide sewage pump-out facilities, provide bilge water management options including low cost or no cost absorbent pads.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-10.pdf

Measure: Prevent the discharge of pollutantsfrom vehicle and equipment main-tenance activities. E.g. provide covered maintenance areas, minimize run-on of stormwater into maintenance area, provide oil/water separators on floor drains.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-11.pdf

Measure: Prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants from vehicle and equipment washing. E.g. Incorporate recycling system to minimize use of clean water and reduce wastes, washing facilities should be bermed to prevent run on of stormwater from nearby surfaces.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-12.pdf

Measure: Prevent or reduce releases fro mvessel repair and maintenance activities: Minimize releases to surface water, Provide adequate stormwater controls, Provide paint booths.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-13.pdf

Measure: To reduce the discharge of pollutants to the air from operation of ships: Encourage ship captains to reach safe distances offshore before achieving full power, Set speed limits for maneuvering near shore, encourage alternative fuels and fuel mixtures.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-14.pdf

Measure: Prevent or reduce the release ofcontaminants during ship breaking activities. E.g. Cover work and storage areas, Scrapping and storage areas should be paved where possible, provide storm water runoff controls for scrapping and storage areas.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-15.pdf

Measure: To reduce the impacts from dredging and dredged materials disposal: Actively  participate  in  watershed  protection  programs  sponsored  by  local  or state  agencies, explore  beneficial  uses  of  dredged  materials  with  regulatory  and  resources agencies.
Source(s): American Association of Port Authorities (AAPA) (1998). Handbook: Environmental Management Practices to address multiple stressors from port activities. https://www.aapa-ports.org/files/PDFs/empo-16.pdf
